prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Observe H26alpha during low state
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Every 5.53 years, the massive binary with a highly eccentric orbit goes into a low ionization state (IP<13.6 eV) resulting in relaxation of the ionized hydrogen structure for two to three months. During that period, the small HII region shrinks but does not disappear, dependent upon residual FUV emission, high Balmer fluxes from the primary star and critical densities. This phenomenon is caused by a hot secondary producing the FUV radiation and carving out a cavity in the dominating LBV primary wind. Detailed 3D hydrodynamic models have been tested using HST/STIS maps of selected forbidden emission lines and are being used to predict the ionized shells in the primary wind due to the periastron passage of the hot secondary. Associated with each of these shells is a compressed, rapidly cooling structure where molecules and dust form.
This observation is planned to measure the residual HI emission, maintained by collisions, strong, broad Balmer emission from the primary star during the low state. Stellar Balmer fluxes are so strong that strong, narrow Halpha through Hdelta absorptions are detected for 2-3" (4600 to 7000AU projected) from the central source.
Fluxes measured in the 2003.5 minimum with ATCA (S. White) was a line peak of 1 Jy on a 12-20 Jy continuum. The high velocity line structure should be about 1/5 this spread over about six elements, or 1/30 or 0.03 Jy. We wish to go to a S/N=5 or limiting 0.07 Jy leading to integration time of 44 minutes plus calibrations, etc.
In addition we record bands above and below the H26 alpha to establish continuum and ensure no other lines are contaminating. We also use the 0.8 km/s channels for emissions narrower than anticipated.

prj:TemporalParameters.prj:note: This observation needs to be done during the low ionization state, brought on by the 2014.6 periastron passage. We expect a ten-fold drop in the total, but non-zero, line flux of H26 alpha due to capture of the FUV by the primary wind as the secondary plunges through periastron. Likely the remaining line flux is due to the high optical depth of hydrogen, keeping many atoms in the metastable 2S state, thuse easily excited to upper levels by visible and longward in wavelength emission.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
FUV radiation from the hot secondary is captured by the primary wind during the two-month long low state. The small H II region will shrink and the wind-wind HI recombination, at densities 10^7-8 cm-3 should disappear.
Strong H21alpha line profile detected during Cycle 0 program with observation less than one minute using 0.3"x0.4" beam.
This observation will see HI line emission originating from high density structure, centered at -52 km/s and non-uniformly distributed over a 0.5"x0.5" region. Based upon 2003.5 observations (S. White personal communication, the total flux should drop ten-fold. Total continuum should be well below the estimated 20 Jy. The -300 and +300 km/s gas likewise will fade, but less so since the ionized metals (Fe, Ni, Co, Sr, Ti, etc) remain ionized due to radiation from the extended primary wind core. HST/STIS observations detected narrow (<40 km/s) Balmer lines spatially distinct from the central broad Balmer wind emission.
We expect weak shell(s) of HI emission moving outward.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Observe H26alpha during high state
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Every 5.53 years, the massive binary with a highly eccentric orbit goes into a low ionization state (IP<13.6 eV) resulting in relaxation of the ionized hydrogen structures for two to three months. During that period, the small HII region relaxes to a minimum, dependent upon residual FUV emission and critical densities. This phenomenon is caused by a hot secondary producing the FUV radiation supporting the ionized region and carving out a cavity in the dominating LBV primary wind. Detailed 3D hydrodynamic models have been tested using HST/STIS maps of selected forbidden emission lines and are being used to predict the ionized shells in the primary wind due to the periastron passage of the hot secondary. Associated with each of these shells is a compressed, rapidly cooling structure where molecules and dust form.
This observation is planned to measure the HI emission during the early stages of recovery of the high state. Models by Garcia, Elhoussieny, Bautista and Kalman (2013 ApJ 775, 8G) will be applied to this data. Total line flux for H28alpha (Abraham poster) shows 90 Jy by 50 km/s during Cycle 0 observation in 2012 summer. Assuming this spread across a 1"x1" area, that leads to 4 Jy average, but assume peak 10 Jyx50 km/s.
The high velocity structure is about 1/5 that level x 250 km/s. and that the structure is spread over a 1"x1" area, or 0.8 Jy spread over 250 km/s. at 25 km/s channel width about 0.08 Jy. We propose to map well below this level. at 0.8mJ s/n=1, should be achievable.
The time constraint is a no earlier than March 2015.
We include bands above and below the H26 alpha line for continuum and to ensure no blends of lines. We also include the 08 km/s channels for structures with line widths narrower than anticipated.

prj:TemporalParameters.prj:note:
The observation can be done from six to eighteen months after the periatron event, or after March 2015. Within three months, the hot secondary star will have carved a growing cavity out of the primary wind, breaking through and ionizing the extended lower density cavity accumulated over multiple 5.53-year cycles.
This time constraint is a no earlier than constraint of March 2015.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
With the creation of a new wind cavity by the secondary, FUV radiation again escapes the primary wind and reionizes the H II region. HI alpha transitions detected by Herschel PACS see a -300 km/s emission as strong as the H II region emission. HIFI sees H40alpha originating from the H II region alone.
Cycle 0 program (Abraham, 2011.0.00497.S) recorded H21alpha profile with less than one minute integration using a 0.3x0.4" beam. Based upon HST/STIS mappings, the -52 km/s emission will resolve into structures surrounding the Weigelt blobs and beyond.
The -300 km/s emission should appear in shell(s) extending out to 0.7" shifting in velocity as it projects closer to Eta Carinae, but well in front. H22alpha line profiles from September 2009 with Herschel/HIFI have peak emission of 0.05K at -350 km/s which should be a feature 0.15-0.4" to the East of Eta Carinae.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Mapping CO 2-1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Despite the Eta Car's ejecta being overabundant in N, underabundant in C and O (relative to solar abundances ~1%), both CO and 13CO show a very strong molecular presence in the Herschel spectra (Gull et al in prep) and as detected by APEX (Loinard et al, 2013, ApJ 749, L4). The molecular ejecta surrounding Eta Carinae is characterized by a 200K gas with velocity range between -150 to +150 km/s and a <40K gas with velocity range -800 to +800 km/s as seen by Herschel HIFI. The low velocity emission originates from the central 4" region but the high velocity emission is from the outer 10"x20" bipolar shell detected of molecular hydrogen in HST/STIS FUV spectra (Gull et al, ApJS) and mapped by XShooter (Teodoro et al, in draft).
We expect to see CO 2-1 throughout the entire Homunculus. Gull et al (ApJS) detected CH, OH, NH, CH+ at -513 km/s with line width ~2.5 km/s in the FUV, but did not see CO in LOS. An upper limit of T<40K was established based upon only the 1-0 rotational transitions seen. By contrast, nearly 1000 H2 lines were detected in the thin interior skin of the HOmunculus being due to UV radiation between 912 to 1700A. These lines disappeared during the low state when FUV is contained by the enveloping primary wind.
While the CO 1-0 line would be included in this proposal, no LO is available.
The CO 3-2 observations had peaks of 0.3K with with of 25 km/s with APEX. These should be resolved to be about 0.3x0.6" or drop 8-fold but multiple by the relative areas^2, so ~40X would yield ~5K. We wish to map to 1/100th or 0.05K achievable in ~30 minutes.
The other selected frequencies provide H30 alpha and higher velocity resolutions in both CO and H30alpha.

prj:TemporalParameters.prj:note: Observation to be scheduled about one year after the low state observation for CO6-5

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We map the entire 10"x20" Homunculus to measure the CO <40K. Note that the data cube will have characteristic scales < 2" due to the extreme velocity ranges (-800 to +800 km/s). Each velocity channel will see structures less than 1" in thickness, but in the form of clumps along distorted ring extending up to 10" in length based upon molecular hydrogen mappings with VLT/XShooter.
APEX observations by Loinard et al measured CO3-2 individual low velocity components at the 0.2K level, but did not extend the velocity range sufficient to detect the high velocity components.
If these structures are 0.2x1" in dimension in the core, then easily detected. If extended components over 2"x2" dimensions, then component would be ~70mK, detectible in the requested integration time. Likely the detected CO will be intermediate between 0.15" clumps and extended features in the Homunculus.
In the central 4" region, the CO may lie in arcuate structures, possibly close to the orbital plane, based upon inferences from the NIR and UV images.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Mapping CO 3-2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Despite the Eta Car's ejecta being overabundant in N, underabundant in C and O (relative to solar abundances ~1%), both CO and 13CO show a very strong molecular presence in the Herschel spectra (Gull et al in prep) and as detected by APEX (Loinard et al, 2013, ApJ 749, L4). The molecular ejecta surrounding Eta Carinae is characterized by a 200K gas with velocity range between -150 to +150 km/s and a <40K gas with velocity range -800 to +800 km/s as seen by Herschel HIFI. The low velocity emission originates from the central 4" region but the high velocity emission is from the outer 10"x20" bipolar shell detected of molecular hydrogen in HST/STIS FUV spectra (Gull et al, ApJS) and mapped by XShooter (Teodoro et al, in draft).
We expect to see CO 3-2 (33K) throughout the Homunculus, but in contrasting levels as the Homunculus caps are thought to be less than 40K for molecules. However molecules in the central region have a kinetic temperature of 200K based upon chemical modeling by J. Black. Based upon HST/STIS mapping (Gull et al in prep; Teodoro et al 2013 ApJ 773, L16) and NIR continuum mapping (Artigau et al, 2011, AJ 141, 202), these structures are hot, dense gas ejected primarily in the 1840s event. This gas likely is excited by the very high infrared radiation from the absorbing,interacting wind structures and collisions.
We scale from APEX observations of peak emissions bein 0.2K with 25 km/s width being spread over 0.2x0.3" 8 beams. Scaling from APEX to ALMA yields about 4.5K. We wish to sample to about 1 percent in the mapping or ~0.05K.
In other bands we include H33beta and continuum.

prj:TemporalParameters.prj:note: Observation to be scheduled about one year after the low state observation for CO6-5

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We map the entire Homunculus in the CO3-2 line. Coupled with the CO2-1 we will be able to limit or measure temperature of the outer Homunculus which based upon CH, OH, NH and CH+ observations with HST/STIS and VLT/UVES is <40K in the outer shell.
Coupled with the CO2-1 and CO6-5, we will be able to measure the temperatures of the central structures close to Eta Carinae. Models by John Black of the many Herschel/SPIRE molecular lines suggest T~200K.
Spatial distribution of the CO emission in the core will provide insight on whether the molecular structures were present before the 1840s event, simply by distance from the central source, were ejected at the time of the 1840s event, or the 1890s lesser event.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Eta Carinae is one of the most luminous binary star systems in our Galaxy. It contains two massive stars, two massive stellar winds, a wind-wind collision zone, an extremely dense ionized nebula, remnants of several eruptions since the early 19th century, and a large quantity of dust of its own making. The abundances of elements (remarkable nitrogen excess, major carbon, oxygen depletions) and isotopes (12C/13C~4) in some of the gas indicate that nucleosynthesized layers of one or more of the stars have already peeled off. Thus Eta Carinae is an excellent laboratory for investigating many of the phenomena that attend the deaths of massive stars. It is shaping an environment that may one day feel the blast from a core-collapse supernova. ALMA is ideally suited in observing frequency, resolution, and sensitivity to reveal the otherwise hidden interactions between ionized and molecular components of gas in the eta Car system. Through ALMA maps of thermal dust emission, hydrogen and helium recombination lines, and CO lines we will be able to analyze the dynamics and composition of winds and ejecta much more clearly than is possible in other parts of the electromagnetic spectrum.
